NATIONAL NEWS






Storm cut power to 8,300 in Forsyth: Homes and businesses were without electricity, cable-television service



Jun. 13--The strong thunderstorm that blew through Winston-Salem and Forsyth County on Monday afternoon knocked down so many power lines that utility crews worked all yesterday to restore electricity.  The storm left more than 8,300 county residents without power immediately after it passed through the county. Most of the outages were caused by tree limbs that fell onto power lines, either ...


Jun 13, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Electricity use rises with heat



Jun. 13--HIGH POINT -- The current respite from the oppressive heat likely will end Sunday, ushering in another spell of 90-plus degree days.  Meanwhile, air conditioners and cooling systems have been going full tilt through the last of May and early June. May 29 was the only day last month that climbed into the 90s, hitting 91, according to Rod Gonski, a National Weather Service meteorologist. ...


Jun 13, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Google, Intel going green: TECH POWERS JOIN PUSH TO SAVE ENERGY WITH MORE EFFICIENT COMPUTERS, SERVERS



Jun. 13--Google and Intel threw their weight behind an initiative Tuesday to help blunt the impact of global warming by bringing greater energy efficiency to personal computers and servers.  An estimated 2 percent of worldwide carbon emissions comes from producing the electricity that powers computers and telecommunications gear. The two high-tech titans hope to reduce that by 54 million tons of ...


Jun 13, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



BPA moves ahead on contracts, formula to share low-cost power



Jun. 12--The Bonneville Power Administration will go ahead negotiating 20-year power-supply contracts with public-utility customers, despite calls by Oregon congressmen to hold off until the BPA figures out how to resume sharing its low-cost hydropower with private utilities.  The federal agency, according to one report for a regional alliance of public-interest groups, also is working on a ...


Jun 12, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Malfunction shuts down Browns Ferry Unit 1 for more testing



Jun. 12--Unit 1 at Browns Ferry Nuclear Plant hit another glitch Saturday, briefly causing an increase in pressure within the reactor vessel, according to Nuclear Regulatory Commission records.  The event, coming after Tennessee Valley Authority hooked Unit 1 to the power grid for the first time in 22 years and after making it to 99-percent power, was a slight setback in the re-start.


Jun 12, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Power outage strikes West Charlotte



Jun. 13--Duke Power and city transportation officials are working to repair problems caused by a power outage this morning in the West Charlotte area.  Some of the power had been restored by 8:50 a.m., but the outage has affected many traffic signals on the west side. Streets involved include Freedom Drive, Wilkinson Blvd, West Blvd and Ashley Road. Duke Power does not know what caused the outage ...


Jun 13, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Starting the sizzle: 100-degree temperatures are forecast to scorch Valley for the rest of the week.



Jun. 13--The first triple-digit temperatures of the year are in the forecast, with highs above 100 degrees expected the rest of this week.  Thursday and Friday could see highs of 106, giving residents an unwelcome reminder of the record temperatures last July, said Gary Sanger, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Hanford. "The forecasted high for [today] is 104, and then it does ...

Tulare Co. OKs power deal: It will join a new Valley group to get lower rates.



Jun. 13--VISALIA -- Tulare County supervisors are moving forward with a power program that will bring competition to the Valley utility business.  In a 4-1 vote, the Board of Supervisors entered an agreement Tuesday with the San Joaquin Valley Power Authority, which says it can provide electricity at lower rates than utility companies to 14 Valley communities.

SAN FRANCISCO / PUC to explore new electricity sources / Inquiry will ask if sun, wind, fuel cells cheaper than PG&E



The San Francisco Board of Supervisors gave approval Tuesday to the San Francisco Public Utilities Commission to explore whether generating electricity from the sun, wind and fuel cells would cost city residents less than what they pay Pacific Gas & Electric Co. for energy. In a series of votes, the board overwhelmingly endorsed a proposal to direct the commission to seek proposals and more ...


Jun 13, 2007 San Francisco Chronicle



Hospital evacuates about 200 after rupture of natural gas line



About 200 people were evacuated from Anne Arundel Medical Center yesterday after a contractor ruptured a natural gas line, a hospital spokeswoman said. Staff members, patients and visitors at the Wayson, Donner and Edwards pavilions at the Annapolis-area hospital were sent outside or to other buildings on the campus shortly before noon, said Effie Dawson, an AAMC spokeswoman.

Portland General Electric's Port Westward Plant available for commercial generation



-- Portland General Electric Company said that its Port Westward Generating Plant, a 40-MW natural gas-fired power plant located near Clatskanie, Ore., is available for commercial generation. The plant is owned and operated by PGE, and is the first major new generating plant placed into service by the company since 1995. It has the capacity to serve approximately 300,000 homes.
